SimHash

a Locality sensitive hash function scheme for Cosine similarity:

  • Let ğ 1,...,ğ râˆˆâ„d\mathbf{g}_1,...,\mathbf{g}_r \in \mathbb{R}^d be randomly chosen with each entry ğ’©(0,1)\mathcal{N}(0,1).
  • Let f:{âˆ’1,1}râ†’{1,â€¦,m}f : \{-1,1\}^r \rightarrow \{1,â€¦,m\} be a Uniformly Random Hash Function.
  • Define the LSH hash function h:â„dâ†’{1,â€¦,m}h: \mathbb{R}^d \rightarrow \{1,â€¦,m\} as: h(x)=f([sign(âŸ¨ğ 1,xâŸ©),...,sign(âŸ¨ğ r,xâŸ©)])h(x) = f([\mathrm{sign}(\langle \mathbf{g}_1,x \rangle),...,\mathrm{sign}(\langle \mathbf{g}_r,x \rangle)])

Proof

Let Î¸=Î¸(ğ±,ğ²)\theta = \theta(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}). Will show that (theorem to prove): Pr[h(ğ±)=h(ğ²)]=(1âˆ’Î¸ğš·+1m)\mathrm{Pr}[h(\mathbf{x}) = h(\mathbf{y})] = (1 âˆ’ \frac{Î¸}{\mathbf{Î }}+\frac{1}{m}) Intermediate result to show that: Pr(âŸ¨ğ ,ğ±âŸ©=âŸ¨ğ ,ğ²âŸ©)=1âˆ’Î¸Ï€\begin{align*} \Pr( \langle \mathbf{g}, \mathbf{x} \rangle = \langle \mathbf{g}, \mathbf{y} \rangle ) = 1 - \frac{\theta}{\pi} \end{align*} Consider random vector ğ \mathbf{g} and its hyperplane. Since it is drawn from the standard normal distribution, the direction of ğ \mathbf{g} is uniformly distributed around the unit circle. Similarly, the hyperplane is also uniformly distributed around the unit circle. TheÂ signÂ of the inner productÂ âŸ¨ğ ,ğ±âŸ©\langle \mathbf{g},\mathbf{x} \rangleÂ specifies which side of the hyperplaneÂ ğ±\mathbf{x}Â is on. Intuitively, the probability thatÂ ğ±\mathbf{x}Â andÂ ğ²\mathbf{y}Â are on the same side of the hyperplane is proportional to their angle.

The probability that they lie onÂ differentÂ sides of the hyperplane is the probability that the random hyperplane falls betweenÂ ğ±\mathbf{x}Â andÂ ğ²\mathbf{y}Â which isÂ 2Î¸2Ï€\frac{2\theta}{2\pi}. Then the probability that they lie on theÂ sameÂ side of the hyperplane isÂ 1âˆ’Î¸Ï€1âˆ’\frac{\theta}{\pi}.

In higher dimensions, we can use the same intuition. There is always some rotation matrixÂ ğ”\mathbf{U}Â such thatÂ ğ”ğ±\mathbf{Ux}Â andÂ ğ”ğ²\mathbf{Uy}Â are spanned by the first two standard basis vectors and have the same cosine similarity asÂ ğ±\mathbf{x}Â andÂ ğ²\mathbf{y}. Then we can apply the result in one dimension toÂ ğ”ğ±\mathbf{Ux}Â andÂ ğ”ğ²\mathbf{Uy}.

SimHash can be tuned, just like our MinHash based function for Jaccard similarity

  • Suppose g1,â€¦,grâˆˆâ„dg_1,â€¦,g_r \in \mathbb{R}^d be randomly chosen with each ğ’©(0,1)\mathcal{N}(0,1).
  • Let f:{âˆ’1,1}râ†’{1,...,m}f: \{-1,1\}^r \rightarrow \{1,...,m\} be a Uniformly Random Hash Function
  • h:â„dâ†’{1,â€¦,m}h: \mathbb{R}^d \rightarrow \{1,â€¦,m\} is defined
  • h(ğ±)=f([sign(âŸ¨ğ 1,ğ±âŸ©),...,sign(âŸ¨ğ r,ğ±âŸ©)])h(\mathbf{x}) = f ([\mathrm{sign}(âŸ¨\mathbf{g}_1, \mathbf{x}âŸ©), . . . , \mathrm{sign}(âŸ¨\mathbf{g}_r, \mathbf{x}âŸ©)]).
  • Pr[h(ğ±)==h(ğ²)]=(1âˆ’Î¸ğš·)r\mathrm{Pr}[h(\mathbf{x}) == h(\mathbf{y})] = (1 âˆ’ \frac{Î¸}{\mathbf{Î }})^r

SimHash(x)=sign(âŸ¨x,tâŸ©)SimHash(x) = \mathrm{sign}(âŸ¨x,tâŸ©) for a random vector tt.
